001/*

006
007package renderer.pipeline;
008
009import renderer.scene.*;
010import renderer.scene.primitives.Primitive;
011import renderer.scene.primitives.Face;
012import renderer.scene.primitives.Triangle;
013import static renderer.pipeline.PipelineLogger.*;
014
015import java.util.List;
016import java.util.ArrayList;
017
018/**
019   This stage is used by the renderer to cull from a {@link Model}'s
020   {@link List} of {@link Primitive}s any {@link Face} that
021   is "back facing".
022<p>
023   The culling of {@link Face} primitives needs to be done before the
024   primitive assembly stage. The culling of {@link Triangle} primitives
025   needs to be done after the primitive assembly stage.
026<p>
027   This stage also implements a simple version of the "painter's algorithm".
028   When backface culling is turned off, this stage still sorts primitives
029   into separate lists of front and back facing primitives. Then the back
030   facing primitives get put into the model's primitive list ahead of the
031   front facing primitives. This causes all the back facing primitives to
032   be rasterized (painted) first, and then all the front facing primitives
033   get rasterized (or, painted) over the back facing ones. The painter's
034   algorithm helps give the renderer a sense of 3D depth.
035<p>
036   For a good explanation of orientation, forward and backward facing
037   polygons, and back face culling, see Chapter 9 of<br>
038      "Computer Graphics Through OpenGL: From Theory to Experiments,"
039      4th Edition, by Sumanta Guha, Chapman and Hall/CRC, 2022.
040<p>
041   That chapter is available online at<br>
042       <a href="https://www.sumantaguha.com/wp-content/uploads/2022/06/chapter9.pdf" target="_top">
043                https://www.sumantaguha.com/wp-content/uploads/2022/06/chapter9.pdf</a>
044*/
045public class BackFaceCulling
046{
047   /**
048      Replace the given {@link Model}'s list of primitives with a
049      new primitive list from which all back facing primitives have
050      been filtered out. Notice that non {@link Face} primitives are
051      considered to be not back facing, so they are kept in the
052      primitive list.
053
054      @param model   {@link Model} whose {@link Primitive} list is to be culled
055      @param camera  the {@link Scene}'s {@link Camera} with the view volume data
056      @return a {@link Model} with culled back faces or the appropriate side of two-sided faces
057   */
058   public static Model cull(final Model model, final Camera camera)
059   {
060      if ( (! model.doBackFaceCulling)
061        && (! model.facesHaveTwoSides) )
062      {
063         return model;
064      }
065
066      final List<Primitive> newPrimitiveList = new ArrayList<>();
067
068      for (final Primitive p : model.primitiveList)
069      {
070         if (! isBackFace(p, model, camera))
071         {
072            // Keep the non-Face primitives and the Face
073            // primitives with the desired orientation.
074            newPrimitiveList.add(p);
075         }
076         else // back facing Face
077         {
078            if ( ! model.doBackFaceCulling )
079            {
080               if ( ! model.facesHaveTwoSides )
081               {
082                  // Keep a back facing Face and
083                  // use its front facing colors.
084                  newPrimitiveList.add(p);
085               }
086               else // faces have two sides
087               {
088                  // Keep a back facing Face but
089                  // use its back facing colors.
090                  final Face p2 = new Face(p.vIndexList,
091                                           ((Face)p).cIndexList2);
092                  newPrimitiveList.add(p2);
093               }
094            }
095         }
096      }
097
098      return new Model(model.vertexList,
099                       newPrimitiveList,
100                       model.colorList,
101                       model.name,
102                       model.getMatrix(),
103                       model.nestedModels,
104                       model.textureList,
105                       model.texCoordList,
106                       model.visible,
107                       model.doBackFaceCulling,
108                       model.frontFacingIsCCW,
109                       model.facesHaveTwoSides);
110   }
111
112
113   /**
114      Determine if a {@link Primitive} is a {@link Face} and if that Face
115      is backward facing. Whether a {@link Face} is back facing or not
116      depends on the {@link Model}'s setting for {@code frontFacingIsCCW}.
117
118      @param p      {@link Primitive} with at least three vertices
119      @param model  {@link Model} that {@code p} comes from
120      @param camera  the {@link Scene}'s {@link Camera} with the view volume data
121      @return true if {@code p} is a back facing {@link Face}
122   */
123   public static boolean isBackFace(final Primitive p,
124                                    final Model model,
125                                    final Camera camera)
126   {
127      return  (p instanceof Face)
128           && ( model.frontFacingIsCCW ^ isCCW(p, model, camera) );
129   //https://docs.oracle.com/javase/specs/jls/se6/html/expressions.html#15.22.2
130   }
131
132
133   /**
134      Determine if a {@link Face} is counterclockwise.
135      <p>
136      This method assumes that the {@link Primitive} {@code p}
137      has at least three vertices so that it can compute two
138      edge vectors and then compute the z-component of their
139      cross product.
140
141      @param p      {@link Primitive} with at least three vertices
142      @param model  {@link Model} that {@code p} comes from
143      @param camera  the {@link Scene}'s {@link Camera} with the view volume data
144      @return true if the {@link Primitive} is counterclockwise
145   */
146   private static boolean isCCW(final Primitive p,
147                                final Model model,
148                                final Camera camera)
149   {
150      // We only need to know the z-component of the cross product
151      // of the two edge vectors, v1-v0 and v2-v0. This works
152      // because the camera is looking down the negative z-axis.
153      final double zValueOfCrossProduct;
154
155      double x0 = model.vertexList.get(p.vIndexList.get(0)).x;
156      double x1 = model.vertexList.get(p.vIndexList.get(1)).x;
157      double x2 = model.vertexList.get(p.vIndexList.get(2)).x;
158      double y0 = model.vertexList.get(p.vIndexList.get(0)).y;
159      double y1 = model.vertexList.get(p.vIndexList.get(1)).y;
160      double y2 = model.vertexList.get(p.vIndexList.get(2)).y;
161      final double z0 = model.vertexList.get(p.vIndexList.get(0)).z;
162      final double z1 = model.vertexList.get(p.vIndexList.get(1)).z;
163      final double z2 = model.vertexList.get(p.vIndexList.get(2)).z;
164
165      // The calculation of orientation needs
166      // to be done with projected coordinates.
167      if ( camera.perspective )
168      {
169         // Calculate the perspective projection.
170         x0 = x0 / -z0;  // xp = xc / -zc
171         x1 = x1 / -z1;
172         x2 = x2 / -z2;
173         y0 = y0 / -z0;  // yp = yc / -zc
174         y1 = y1 / -z1;
175         y2 = y2 / -z2;
176      }
177
178      zValueOfCrossProduct = (x1-x0)*(y2-y0) - (y1-y0)*(x2-x0);
179
180      if (PipelineLogger.debugScene || PipelineLogger.debugPosition)
181      {
182         System.err.println( "4. Culling_1: " + p.toString() );
183         System.err.printf("-- zValueOfCrossProduct = % .26f\n",
184                               zValueOfCrossProduct);
185         System.err.print( (0 <= zValueOfCrossProduct) ? "-- CCW, "
186                                                       : "-- CW, " );
187         System.err.println(
188            (model.frontFacingIsCCW ^ (0 <= zValueOfCrossProduct))
189            ? "Back face"
190            : "Front face");
191      }
192
193      return 0 <= zValueOfCrossProduct;
194   }
195
196
197
198   // Private default constructor to enforce noninstantiable class.
199   // See Item 4 in "Effective Java", 3rd Ed, Joshua Bloch.
200   private BackFaceCulling() {
201      throw new AssertionError();
202   }
203}
